title: Richie Karl
text:
Richard Karl (born September 28, 1944) is an American <a href="professional%20golfer">professional golfer</a> who is best known as the last <a href="golf">golf</a> club professional to win an official <a href="PGA%20Tour">PGA Tour</a> event.
Karl was born in <a href="Johnson%20City%2C%20New%20York">Johnson City, New York</a>. He played college golf at <a href="Florida%20State%20University">Florida State University</a>. He won the Alaska State Amateur twice while stationed in the Army there.
Karl turned professional in 1968. He won the 1974 <a href="B.C.%20Open">B.C. Open</a> by sinking a 35-foot putt on the first hole in a playoff with <a href="Bruce%20Crampton">Bruce Crampton</a>. Karl, who worked at the En-Joie Golf Club in <a href="Endicott%2C%20New%20York">Endicott, New York</a> where the B.C. Open was played and lived along the 10th fairway, is the last club professional to win on the PGA Tour.
Karl played briefly on the Senior PGA Tour (now <a href="Champions%20Tour">Champions Tour</a>) starting after he turned 50 in September 1994. His best finish in this venue was a T-5 at the <a href="ACE%20Group%20Classic">ACE Group Classic</a>. In 2007, Karl played as a sponsor's exemption in the inaugural <a href="Dick%27s%20Sporting%20Goods%20Open">Dick's Sporting Goods Open</a>, a Champions Tour event played on his home course.
Professional wins (6).
PGA Tour wins (1).
